image.altText: A woman in a red blazer sits next to a woman in a black dress.

items.synopsis: Follow our live blog for the latest news in the lead-up to voting in the referendum on October 14.

title.children: ABC journalists Carly Williams, Fran Kelly and analyst Antony Green answer your questions on the Voice

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The government says the Voice is designed to improve Indigenous lives and Close the Gap. Carly Williams says while some Close the Gap targets are on track others are going backwards. "What we are seeing worsening is early childhood development, adults in prison, children in out-of-home care and Indigenous suicide rates," she said. "We don'thave a crystal ball to know if the Voice is going to magically fix this, especially how fast that can happen." Fran Kelly says the argument put forward by those supporting the Voice is that is will be hearing from grassroots communities that will be coming up with ideas on what would work. Williams says that history shows that when mob are part of the decision-making process it results in the most fruitful outcomes. "This is aboutself-determination, that is what the government and Yes advocates say," she says.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: How can a Voice improve Indigenous lives?

children.content: The government says the Voice is designed to improve Indigenous lives and Close the Gap.
Carly Williams says while some Close the Gap targets are on track others are going backwards.
"What we are seeing worsening is early childhood development,
adults in prison, children in out-of-home care and Indigenous suicide rates," she said.
"We don'thave a crystal ball to know if the Voice is going to magically fix this, especially how fast that can happen."
Fran Kelly says the argument put forward by those supporting the Voice is that is will be hearing from grassroots communities that will be coming up with ideas on what would work.
Williams says that history shows that when mob are part of the decision-making process it results in the most fruitful outcomes.
"This is aboutself-determination, that is what the government and Yes advocates say," she says.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: ABC journalists Carly Williams and Fran Kelly are answering your questions on the Voice referendum. You can watch it live via the stream below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Your questions on the Voice referendum answered

children.content: ABC journalists
Carly Williams
and
Fran Kelly
are answering your questions on the Voice referendum
You can watch it live via the stream below.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Jess McGuire Chair of the Murrawarri Peoples Council in Far North West NSW, Fred Hooper will be voting No on the Voice to Parliament at the referendum – because he feels as though it doesn't go far enough. He also believes First Nations communities around the country should have been properly polled to see if there was strong support for a Voice to Parliament from Indigenous people in the first place. "I think that there should have been a plebiscite of the First Nations people first. And if that would have occurred, and we'd have got the majority of (our) people voting in that plebiscite saying 'Yes, we want to want to have a Voice' then my views probably would have changed as well from the current view that I have" He also told the ABC that regardless of the referendum result, it's all meaningless unless the British Crown formally apologised to Indigenous peoples of Australia, as it did in 1995 when during a visit to New Zealand, Queen Elizabeth II personally delivered an apology from the British Crown to the Tainui people. Mr Hooper says he'd welcome a visit from King Charles III to Bourke in Western NSW where the head of the British monarchy could "deliver the apology on Murrawarri country on behalf of The Crown to the First Nations people of this country".
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Chair of the Murrawarri Peoples Council voting No in referendum

props.alt: A man stands in front of a lake wearing a blue shirt.

children.content: Fred Hopper says he will be voting no in the referendum.
(One Plus One: The Elders)

image.altText: A man looks at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

title.children: ASX up slightly, Reserve Bank says small but rising shares of households in financial stress

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's not the news we want to hear on a Friday afternoon, but it's the reality for thousands of us — more Australian households are seeking financial counselling and are on the cusp of financial stress, if they're not experiencing it already. That's according to the RBA's latest Financial Stability Review, which we've mentioned a bit on the blog today because it's essentially the central bank's temperature check of how the financial system (and our economy) is going and what risks lie ahead. It's kind of like our annual general health check up with our doctors, except the RBA does this twice a year. The main takeaways are really around the fact inflation and interest rates are still a big problem, and that's flowing through to a small group of borrowers with their mortgages — but that group is growing. The report notes that the share of owner-occupiers with variable rate mortgages that had expenses exceeding their income in July this year was around 5% — up from 1% in April 2022. That means they have little capacity to cut back on spending, and 30% of them are at risk of depleting their savings buffers, so are at higher risk of falling into arrears. And although there has been a substantial increase in calls to the National Debt Helpline, there's only a "very small share of borrowers" who are in negative equity, or when the value of their loan exceeds the value of their property. If you want some more detail about the review, senior business correspondent Peter Ryan has you covered:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Financial stress is growing for households, but the RBA says the banking system isn't at risk

featuredLink.title: A rising number of households on the cusp of financial stress, says Reserve Bank

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: If you missed it yesterday, Australians are being pushed into living in granny flats, share houses, or taking up house-sitting as the rental market keeps getting tighter. Vacancy rates have hit a record low, with tenants paying around 30% more than they were just three years ago. Business reporter Emilia Terzon spoke to renters who are in these situations and how it's affecting them — you can watch her full story below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 📺 ICYMI: Rising rents and property values are pushing Aussies into granny flats

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: This is certainly not a sentence I would write today — but former US president Donald Trump reportedly discussed "potentially sensitive" details about America's nuclear submarine program with Australian cardboard and packaging billionaire Anthony Pratt. The American ABC news outlet has reported that Mr Trump told Mr Pratt the supposed number of nuclear warheads on US submarines, and how close they could get to a Russian submarine without being detected. The conversation is said to have taken place at Mr Trump's Mar-a-Lago club in Florida several months after he left office. The alleged conversation was not mentioned by federal prosecutors when they charged the former president with mishandling classified material, but ABC is reporting Mr Pratt — who is the chairman of paper and packaging companies, Visy and Pratt Industries — was interviewed. The American ABC news outlet has no affiliation with ABC News here in Australia. Mr Pratt has been contacted for comment and is not accused of wrongdoing, while a spokesperson for Mr Trump criticised what he called "illegal leaks" and said he'd always acted lawfully. You can read more about this story from North America bureau chief Jade Macmillan below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Donald Trump accused of sharing nuclear submarine details with Anthony Pratt

featuredLink.title: Donald Trump accused of sharing nuclear submarine details with Australian billionaire
